meanings.definition: To incline upward or be turned upward
meanings.sent1: She tried to steeve the painting on the wall to get a better view.
meanings.sent2: The road started to steeve as it reached the top of the hill.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to steeve its head to look at the bird on the tree.
meanings.sent4: His excitement seemed to steeve higher as the concert drew closer.
meanings.sent5: The kite began to steeve higher and higher in the sky as the wind picked up.

meanings.definition: A spar or boom that is inclined upward at an angle from a mast
meanings.sent1: The ship's steeve was damaged during the storm.
meanings.sent2: The sailors adjusted the steeve to catch more wind for the sail.
meanings.sent3: The seagull perched on the steeve of the ship, enjoying the view.
meanings.sent4: The steeve of the tree branch reached out like a welcoming hand.
meanings.sent5: The steeve of the flagpole stood tall against the blue sky.
